It is not possible to represent a java.util.GregorianCalendar daylight savings timezone id in the XML Schema 1.0 date/time datatype representation. To compute the return value's TimeZone field, when this.getTimezone() != FIELD_UNDEFINED, create a java.util.TimeZone with a custom timezone id using the this.getTimezone(). else use the GregorianCalendar default timezone value for the host is defined as specified by java.util.TimeZone.getDefault().

Returns: New Duration created with the specified durationInMilliseconds.
Parameters: long: Milliseconds of Duration to create.
newDurationDayTime(long).Description: Create a Duration of type xdt:dayTimeDuration using the specified milliseconds as defined in The datatype xdt:dayTimeDuration is a subtype of xs:duration whose lexical representation contains only day, hour, minute, and second components. This datatype resides in the namespace http://www.w3.org/2003/11/xpath-datatypes. All four values are set by computing their values from the specified milliseconds and are available using the get methods of the created @B_javax#xml#datatype#Duration_E@. The values conform to and are defined by: ISO 8601:2000(E) Section 5.5.3.2 Alternative format @B_javax#xml#datatype#XMLGregorianCalendar_E@ Date/Time Datatype Field Mapping Between XML Schema 1.0 and Java Representation The default start instance is defined by @B_java#util#GregorianCalendar_E@'s use of the start of the epoch: i.e., @B_java#util#Calendar#YEAR_E@ = 1970, @B_java#util#Calendar#MONTH_E@ = @B_java#util#Calendar#JANUARY_E@, @B_java#util#Calendar#DATE_E@ = 1, etc. This is important as there are variations in the Gregorian Calendar, e.g. leap years have different days in the month = @B_java#util#Calendar#FEBRUARY_E@ so the result of @B_javax#xml#datatype#Duration#getDays_E@ can be influenced. Any remaining milliseconds after determining the day, hour, minute and second are discarded.
